I understand the appeal of the message, but Brazil is a very complex society and although has laws for everything, it lacks the basic pillars of developed societies and thus presents many conflicts including this one. I'm privileged to understand this here. Although I hate politics, I had to manifest my opinion since I care about what you present in this channel also when it affects me even indirectly. Thanks.

Im Brazilian and I know exactly whats going on here, bolsonaro is a corrupt politician that only wants to serve those who paid for his campaing, despite left or right the amazoon needs to be protected at all costs!

‚Äã@Katy Maloney Well.. I appreciate the effort you put into this reply. You seem educated and caring. But you did not pay attention to what I said. Let me try and be more clear. I completely agree on environmental issues, extractivist development and such. I also think laws need to be better enforce and Amazon has to be protected and all of that. Youtube isn't clearly the place to argue what needs to be done. But past mistakes were evidently made and will continue to be made. You see.. I also care about our world deeply, not just Amazon or Brazil. But in nowadays society, including Brazil... citizen alienation in virtue of culture doesn't work anymore. And it seems.. you have loaded opinions. What I can tell you is this: We don't need more activists here. Do your best in Canada. Peace.

I've been working with brazilian scholars, I've met caboclos, indigenous groups, riberinhos, I visited Manaus, Santarem, Belem, all across the Amazon region, and am sorry to say, I think YOU might be slightly biased here.. There are opposing views of development at war. The common view that places economic development at odds with natural conservation is called extractivist development. Theirs is ecocentric and it understands the concequences of extractivist development, because they feel them directly and never seem to reap the so-called rewards when they do sacrifice a piece of land to soy monoculture or illegal logging... it's not bias so much as experience. I'm from Canada, and we have the same issues with viewing first nations and indigenous locals as less knowledgeable than us when it comes to land usage and management, but they're not the ones causing global warming, or flooding rivers with toxic mining residue... They're the ones that showed you how to get rubber from seringeira trees, without them, no ciclo da borracha, and yet they suffered more from helping you out, being brought into slavery and decimated by violent encroaching on their lands all over south america. That still goes on to this day, as indigenous communities still fight back those encroachers, who are armed with more than just great speeches on development.. The majority of environmental activists murdered in the world are murdered in the brazilian campo... Just because your elites keep you poor and undereducated, doesn't mean you can just steal other people's lands and destroy them for profit. And you can't steal people's stuff and then ask them to pay you, can't have the bread and the money for the bread... one or another's gotta give. But respect where respect is due, know your own history, consider how much these "biased" people have endured before judging their way of life as unproductive and thus, unworthy of protection. Land management as we know it was invented in England before the industrial revolution (agrarian capitalism, "improvement", privatization of communal lands, "far west" policies, etc.), and what was right for them then (arguably) can't be right for everyone everywhere at all times. Maximizing land usage and concentrating it into the hands of the few is a problem and a main cause of poverty, not a solution to poverty. Small farmers clear the land, but latifundios buy them back, they do the hard work and can never really reap the benefits either. It's a well studied structure... "Free development" of the Amazon is the worse case scenario, for all parties... it will not lead to more social justice, never has, never will.

author_name: May the Science be with You
text: All I see is more environmentalists disappear and getting murdered. And nobody cares about those unsung heroes who endanger their own life to protect what should be most important. Instead I see people mocking them and saying that it is their own fault and they were stupid for wasting their life for something this nonsensical, instead of trying to get rich. The problem with humanity is not that we have many horrible, psycopathic people in power who exploit the world, the problem is that the majority of people simple doesn't care. People give a shit about thing that don't concern them (their wallet) directly. Most people are only concerned with themselves and their own petty problems. They don't want to be bothered with such things. Most people only care about their own convenience. Eating less meat, producing less trash, not buying that mahogany table would cut into their convenient lifestyle and they don't want that.

its in this times that celebrities, common people, national geographic, anyone or any known organization with political influence or with sources should unite and do something about whats happening to this forest. i grew up watching national geographic about how beautiful and important the amazon rainforest is. i watched how national geographic has become rich by their documentaries yet now when one of their profits is in big trouble i never heard any protests coming from them. its heartbreaking watching the destruction of that forest i swore to visit some day. it tears my heart seeing its people, plants and animals lose their loved ones and homes through the greed of companies wanting that forest for money and power. im just a simple driver and i want to help, to give back to the environment. if anyone here has any ideas how i could help, please give some suggestions. üò≠üò≠üò≠

The malediction of abundance, as Alberto Acosta would call it. Very true. Even in Canada, we might seem very lucky compared to Brazil, but then our mining companies are amongst the worse corporate citizens of the world, helping pillage other countries to help finance our "growth". The issue isn't choosing between one or the other, preservation or development, but we need to realize that our development strategies are perhaps outdated and need to change... It's like we're trying to solve some quantum equation with a abacus. "More beaaads! We need more beaaads!" Maybe you never needed the beads, maybe in fact, the beads are keeping you from seeing the bigger (smaller) picture...! Failing to recognize that extractivism is a problem, not a solution for all mankind, is becoming an old problem. Fast. For all nations, not just those cursed by a history of colonialism.

Dear Mr. Jefferson! You think we want to influence your politics. Yes, if that were the case we Europeans would also not want Brazilians to tell us to safe something. But because it produces so much oxygen and is the only hope for the life on this planet, we are deeply concerned about what is happening. Even football star Ronaldo said it would be disastrous if the forest burned further. If your life were in danger with a project we do in Europe, we would of course let you tell us what we should do, since we want to see you healthy too. Since I feel you are a responsible and honorable man, I guess you understand our concern. :)

@Jefferson SSantos First of all, thanks for taking the time to read the article. I hope you learned something. Having said that, the Amazon is an amazing place. It has more biodiversity than any other place on earth. It sequesters more carbon dioxide than any other land biome on earth. More than 20% of the world‚Äôs oxygen is produced by the Amazon. It's the largest tropical rainforest on earth! So, I think, as most people probably do, that it it worthy of being protected and not destroyed. Brazil is a huge country. It has tons of space, and it can develop itself in many other ways, while not destroying the Amazon.

Id love to see the developed nations designate >50% of their OWN territory to the preservation of the native forrest that used to exist in their territory. It's easy to point the finger at Brazil because it still has 60% of their territory in pristine conditions, when those criticising and pointing their fingers live in nations that have completely depleted their land resources, arguably becoming developed for doing exactly that. You want the Amazon preserved? How about financially incentivising Brazil to NOT use their own resources? How about taxing the rich nations that emit the CO2 the Brazilian Amazon helps reabsorb? How about that CO2 tax? In the mean time... go ahead Brazil, take advantage of your resources in whichever means necessary to better the lives of your own people.. do the exact same way all the other nations are doing. Go Bolsonaro.

Your arguments are in the face of the people trying to protect the forest, just as the ancestors in the in other developed nations would have fought to protect theirs. They had no voice but now the people of the Amazon have. You cant use the wrongs of the past to justify the wrongs of the present, especially not in the face of what we know now about our planet. I live in the UK where we have no large forest left. So tell me how our economy survives without exploiting natural resources in the way you propose Brazil should?

@Maria sure sounds all good and dandy, but then you agree that the root of the problem isn't the deforestation of the Amazon but rather the world's wealth distribution.. Therefore my argument is still the same, as long as the wealthy nations and the megarich don't do their fair share they shouldn't be pointing their fingers at the little guy trying to grow. Sure the deforestation will like make a few extremely wealthy.. But as long as the poor make 1% more than they did the year before, that 1% might equal feeding their children better or going hungry. It means nothing to you, but it means the world to them. Btw Brazil signed the Paris agreement, what world superpower didn't because it would "hinder" their growth? I say if other nations won't reach an agreement, Brazil should act on their own benefits. Even if it means we are all doomed in the end.

How about educating yourself from mistakes done by other nations and doing better then they did? Where do you think most of the money from deforestation went in the past? In all the fantastic president/minister/King/_ lovely pockets! Majority of wealth is put back to the wealthy. All your Brazilian people and you and your children will be left with in 15 years is dirty & shitty air. Learn from the past.
